lessonOverview.title: Unit 5 - Lesson 2
structures: A: What time do you get up?
B: I get up at seven thirty.
A: What time does he/she have breakfast?
B: He/She has breakfast at eight fifteen.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six daily activities (get up, have breakfast, go to school, have lunch, have dinner, go to bed) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show daily routine visuals. Say: “Have breakfast.” Students repeat and put flashcards in order of a typical day.
stretchStrategies: In groups, students interview each other and then write and present a mini-report about one classmate’s daily routine, using third person (e.g., “He gets up at... She goes to bed at...”)

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about daily activities using “What time do you...?” / “What time does he/she...?” and respond with “I/He/She... at (time).”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Ask: “What time do you have lunch?” Model: “I have lunch at twelve.” Students ask and answer in pairs using routine visuals + clock prompts.
stretchStrategies: In groups, students interview each other and then write and present a mini-report about one classmate’s daily routine, using third person (e.g., “He gets up at... She goes to bed at...”)

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What time do you ___?” / “What time does he/she ___?” / “I/He/She ___ at ___.” to talk about daily activities.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write sentence frame: “What time does he/she ___?” Students complete and answer with a partner using daily activity flashcards.
stretchStrategies: In groups, students interview each other and then write and present a mini-report about one classmate’s daily routine, using third person (e.g., “He gets up at... She goes to bed at...”)

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
